comments:
Created an attachment (id=77514)
Report design

The attached report was created using BIRT 2.0.1. It uses scripting to set the highlight color to orange for every alternate row in the table including the group and detail row.

When this is opened in 2.2.1 August 31st build and previewd, the entire table becomes orange.

Created an attachment (id=77515)
Expected report output

There are some logical modification between build 2.0.1 and 2.2.1.
In BIRT 2.0.1:
We evaluate the expression in highlight rule one time when execute a result set row. So in the attached report design, the hightlights on row-item and data-item will get the same evaluation results.

In BIRT 2.2.1:
We evaluate their own highlight rules when execute the item and its children.
In the attached report design, we first handle the highlight on Row-item, then handle the 'count++' operation, then handle the highlight on Data-item in the Row-item, so we get the different result between Row-item and Date-item. That's the reason why we get different result between two BIRT build.

Thanks.

set WONTFIX.

Can you please provide a workaround in 2.2.1 that allows me to alternate colors on every row even if there is grouping in the table? This is a common requirement. I need to understand how to accomplish this result.

and here is a new report design which has been tested in "preview" and "web viewer" in birt build 2.2.1.

set WONTFIX.

Thanks.

In the report design, the user increase myCounter in onRender and uses it in the highlight.

The highlight is executed in generation time while onRender is executed in rendering time, so it not works in renderTask as the in renderTask, the generating and rendering is divided into two task.

The user should define and use myCount in same scope, either generation time on render time.

To define and use it in generation time, the user should define myCount in onCreate and use in either highlight or change it in onCreate.

To define and use it in render time, the user should define myCount in onRender and change the style through onRender script.

traces.message: There are errors evaluating script "if ( (myCounter % 2) == 0 ){ this.getStyle().backgroundColor = "red";}":{1}.
There are errors evaluating script "if ( (myCounter % 2) == 0 ){ this.getStyle().backgroundColor = "red"; this.getStyle().color="red";}":{1}.
